timeline.bodyText:
I wonder what it means where we fail here.
I assume the correct behaviour of this service kind of depends upon receiving the events.
Isn't logging a warning good manners?
timeline.author: jbee

replies.bodyText:
If events aren't present it means it won't be listening to the internal event bus.
It's only used in the next method, listening for when an application is unloaded so as to remove the tracer for that particular application.
I can add a warning though instead of just carrying on
replies.author: Pandrex247

replies.bodyText: If missing the event is no biggie no warning is needed IMHO.
replies.author: jbee

timeline.bodyText: Is there a reason to not have these injected and kept in a field?
timeline.author: jbee

replies.bodyText:
Same reason as given above.
Injection attempts to start the service, something not necessarily desired when running on a Java SE client.
Particularly important for this service since it starts at run level 10, whereas starting via injection is typically run level -2. While I could make it non-validating, request tracing has quite a big chain of other services it injects which I'd also have to make non-validating.
Simply checking if the service is actually running before checking if it's enabled seems cleaner.
